                               JUDGMENT

(24/12/2018) Per Vivek Agarwal, J.

Criminal Appeal No.744/2005 originates out of 2 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 judgment dated 30.09.2005 passed by the Second Additional Sessions Judge, Guna to the First Additional Sessions Judge, Guna in Sessions Trial No.185/1998, whereby appellants have been convicted under Section 302 of IPC with the aid of Section 34 of IPC and sentenced to Life Imprisonment and fine of Rs.2,000/-; in default of payment of fine, further 1 year's R.I. Criminal Appeal No.294/2015 has been filed by the appellant being aggrieved by judgment dated 26.02.2015 passed by the Court of the third Additional Sessions Judge, Guna in Sessions Trial No.185/1998, whereby appellant has been convicted under Section 302 of IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment and fine of Rs. 200/-; in default of payment of fine, further 6 months R.I. (2) Brief facts leading to present appeals are that, as per the prosecution, on 15.04.1998 at about 8:15 am, in the vicinity of Ganesh Talkies Guna, Anil Kumar and his accomplices with a common intention and common object committed homicidal murder of Vivek S/o Kabul Chand wherein Sudhir had thrown red chili powder on the face of the deceased Vivek, whereas allegation is that Vinod had held hands of Vivek when Anil another appellant had caused injury with the help of a skewer (katar) which resulted in his death.

(3) It is not in dispute that deceased Vivek s/o Kabul Chand was having a Gumty (shop) to sell pan (betel). On 15.04.1998 at about 8:15 am, he was going with his brother Pramod Kumar (PW-1) to open said shop from his house situated at Dubey Colony, Guna. When they reached slightly ahead of Ganesh Talkies, Vinod, Sudhir and Anil came and obstructed way of Vivek. Accused Anil asked him 3 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 as to why he had beaten him yesterday, then Vinod had caught hold of Vivek from the front then accused Sudhir had put red chili powder on his face which had entered his eye and thereafter Anil had taken out a skewer (katar) and had hit below his right arm, second blow was given on left hand side of the stomach, as a result of which Vivek started bleeding and had fallen down on floor. Some people collected when Pramod shouted. By that time, Anil, Vinod and Sudhir threatening the accused started running towards the railway line situated at B.G. road. Pramod (PW-1) had taken Vivek to the hospital where he was declared brought died. FIR (Exhibit P-1) was lodged on 15.04.1998 at 9:50 Am. It is also not in dispute that safina form (Exhibit P-2) was issued and Naksha Panchayatnama of dead body (Exhibit - P-3) was prepared in which it is mentioned that Vivek died of two stab wounds injuries. In the postmortem report (Exhibit P-9), cause of death has been shown to be on account of antimortem injuries to vital organs of body leading to hemorrhages, shock and death. Death occurred within six hours of postmortem which was conducted at 11:00 Am by a team of two doctors, namely, Dr. P.K. Gupta and Dr. M.K. Jain. One of them, Dr. P.K. Gupta has been examined as PW-11 in the case.

(4) Learned counsel for the appellants in criminal appeal No.744/2005 submits that appellants are innocent and they have been falsely implicated on account of earlier rivalry. Emphasis has been laid on evidence of defence witness Deepak Mishra (DW-1) who according to the appellants is having a grocery shop at matkary building, Ganesh Talkies- Bajrangarh road. It is submitted that as per deposition of Deepak Mishra (DW-1), he was taking out 4 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 his counter while opening his shop when he saw two persons arguing on some point and then he saw that one of them was lying on the floor and other person had stabbed him and ran away. According to him, several shopkeepers including Mohan Singh had collected. In cross- examination, he admitted that he had taken such person to the hospital and the person who had stabbed the deceased was caught by the police personnel. He also deposed that he had not heard any noise of cries on stab wound being caused to the deceased. He also admitted that he was knowing the deceased before incident as he was running a shop of paan (betel). He further deposed that family member of the deceased had not met him on way but had met in the hospital. In view of such deposition which is read with testimony of Dr. P.K. Gupta (PW-11) that in Para 9 of his cross-examination, he has admitted that if injuries would have been superficial and would not have been cut through the lungs then deceased could have been saved. This statement is read in conjunction with statement of Karan Singh Bhadoriya (PW-3) who has deposed that he is working as Constable in City Kotwali Guna and was deputed on duty at bus stand with effect from 01.04.1998, his duty timing was 6:00 am to 6:00 pm. It is pointed out that this prosecution witness who had caught hold of Anil Bhargava who was on run has deposed in Para 6 of his cross-examination that when he had searched clothes of Anil, he had found one skewer (katar) from his pocket. He has also pointed out that though this witness has admitted that several hotels and tea shops were opened but none of the independent person has been cited as prosecution witness. In para 10, Karan Singh Bhadoriya (PW-3) has admitted that he had also found something like red chili 5 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 sticking to the hands of Anil and similar material was found in the right side pant pocket of Anil. Pointing out towards such evidence, it is submitted that it was Anil who alone had given affect to such incident and other persons have been falsely implicated.

(5) Learned counsel for the appellants also submits that there are several shortcomings in the evidence of Pramod Kuamr (PW-1) so called eye witness in regard to role of Vinod. At one point of time, this witness submits that Vinod had held hands of Vivek from front and then in cross-examination, he submits that Vinod had held hands of Vivek from behind. It is submitted that Pramod (PW-1) is a doubtful witness inasmuch as there was no attempt on his part to save Vivek and secondly if he was present on the spot, he himself had taken Vivek to the hospital who was profusely bleeding, police has not seized any cloth of Pramod Kumar to show that he had sustained blood stains on account of handling of his brother Vivek. It is also pointed out that though this witness has admitted presence of several persons on the spot and did not deny presence of Mohan Dhakad, Deepak Mishra, Sanju Maratha & Nirmal Agarwal on the spot, but the fact is that no independent eye witness has been examined and another so called eye witness is Manish Jain (PW-2) another person from the same community to which deceased Vivek belongs. It is pointed out that Manish Jain (PW-2) claims himself to be friend of deceased along with one Ajay, but in para 14 he has deposed that he had stayed at the spot of incident for 10-12 minutes, then they had taken Vivek to hospital in commander jeep and then he left the hospital after dropping Vivek at the hospital. He has clearly deposed that he was not aware as to what procedure was 6 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 carried out in the hospital. By reading such statements of Manish Jain (PW-2), it is pointed out that he is a planted witness and has not seen the incident inasmuch as this witness has admitted that at the time of incident he was not in job. If he was not in job, then there was no urgency to leave his friend who was profusely bleeding at the time of incident. It is submitted that this fortifies their belief that Manish Jain (PW-2) is a planted witness. Similarly, Ajay Kumar Jain (PW-5) is also from the same community, though his presence has been shown by Manish Jain (PW-

2) but he has turned hostile and has not supported prosecution story.

(6) Rajiv Jain (PW-9) is a witness to the seizure of blood stained soil etc. and is not an eye witness. Faim Khan (PW-10) is a witness of Safina form (Exhibit P-2) and Naksha Panchayatnama (Exhibit P-3). Mahesh Kumar Sharma (PW-12) is witness of seizure of skewer (katar) but he has deposed that the said skewer (katar) was not seized in front of him and he is not sure whether Anil was sitting there or not. He has largely not supported the case of prosecution.

(7) Thus, it is pointed out that as per prosecution there are three eye witnesses Pramod Kumar Jain (PW-1), Manish Jain (PW-2) & Ajay Kumar Jain (PW-5). Ajay has turned hostile. Presence of Manish is doubtful so also that of Pramod Kumar Jain. There are no independent witnesses and therefore it is a fit case for acquittal.

(8) Learned counsel for the appellants has placed reliance on the law laid down by the Division Bench of this Court in case of Basant Lal and Another Vs. State of M.P., as reported in ILR [2009] M.P. 1431, wherein in 7 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 an appeal, the Division Bench held that appellant who had caught hold the deceased when appellant No.1 caused knife injury and appellant No.1 did not utter a single word before dealing knife blows. He also did not exhorted to appellant No.2 to catch hold the deceased then it can be held that appellant No.2 was not having knowledge that suddenly appellant No.1 could cause knife blow. Thus, it was held that there were no circumstances to hold that appellant No.2 was sharing common intention. He was held guilty of wrongfully confining the deceased and was acquitted of Section 302/34 of IPC and was convicted under Section 342 of IPC.

(9) Similarly, reliance has been placed on the judgment of Supreme Court in case of Pandurang and Others Vs. State of Hyderabad, reported in, AIR 1955 SC 216, wherein Hon'ble Supreme Court has dealt with issue of applicability and scope of Section 34 of IPC and has held that in the case of Section 34, it is well established that a common intention presupposes prior concert. It requires a prearranged plan because before a man can be vicariously convicted for the criminal act of another, the act must have been done in furtherance of the common intention of them all.

(10) Reliance has also been placed on the judgment of Supreme Court in case of Mohtesham Mohd. Ismail Vs. Special Director, Enforcement Directorate and Another, [2007 (8) SCC 254], wherein the ratio of law is that as per the provisions contained in Section 30 of the Evidence Act, 1872, what will be the evidentiary value and use of confession of co-accused. It has been held that it cannot be treated as substantive evidence. It can be 8 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 pressed into service only when the Court is inclined to accept other evidence and feels the necessity of seeking for an assurance in support of the conclusion deducible therefrom.

(11) Learned counsel for the appellant-Anil in Criminal Appeal No.294/2015 has placed reliance on law laid down by Supreme Court in case of Surain Singh Vs. State of Punjab, as reported in, 2017 (1) Crimes 137 (SC), wherein the Supreme Court holding that attack was not premeditated and preplanned and appellant accused had inflicted injuries which though were not on the vital organs proved fatal held that appellant accused neither acted cruelly nor took undue advantage of deceased as scuffle had taken place in heat of passion and thus recording a finding that case is covered by exception 4 under section 300 IPC modified conviction from Section 302 to one Section 304 Part 2 of IPC.

(12) As far as appellant Anil is concerned, his case cannot be said to be covered with the law laid down in case of Surian Singh (Supra) inasmuch as in said case attack was not premeditate and pre-planned, injuries were inflicted on non vital organs and appellant accused had neither acted cruelly nor taken undue advantage of deceased and lastly scuffle took place in heat of passion.

(13) Contrary to the facts as in the case of Surain Singh (Supra) as discussed above, as far as Anil is concerned, scuffle had not taken place in heat of passion but there was a rivalry being carried forward atleast from a day earlier. Planning part can be seen from the fact that Anil had taken out skewer (katar) from his pocket of trouser as if it would not have been planned then Anil 9 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 would not have been carrying a skewer (katar) in his pocket. Also the blows were on vital parts and this fact is corroborated by Dr. P.K. Gupta (PW-11), who had conducted postmortem and found that the first wound was blow right armpit near fifth rib measuring 6 cm x 2 cm and its edges were sharply cut and blood was flowing out from it. Second blow was on the left hand side of the stomach having edges of 2 cm x 1 cm upto internal tissues. As a result of such injuries right plural cavity was full of blood and right lung had a cut of 3 cm x 2 cm on the lower side resulting in collapse of the lung. Even dome of diaphragm was cut and blood was collecting in the plurals cavity. Right diaphragm had a cut of 3 cm x 2 cm and there was a small wound even in the small intestine. There was another wound in liver measuring 3 cm x 2 cm with sharp cut ends. Therefore, case of Anil is not covered by the ratio of law laid down in case of Surain Singh (Supra). Since in FSL report (Exhibit C-2), blood stains were found on katar (Exhibit P-10) recovered from Anil and his shirt (Article-E), his conviction cannot be faulted with.

(14) Presence of Pramod Kumar (PW-1) cannot be doubted merely because his clothes were not seized by the Police, as for the fault of the I.O., whole prosecution story cannot be discarded. Presence of Pramod Kumar (PW-1) is evident from the postmortem report (Exhibit P-9) at 10:45 Am, whereas suggestion of defence to him is that he was away from Guna on the day of incident. Postmortem Doctor, Dr. P.K. Gupta (PW-11) has no vested interest in showing his presence at the particular time and he has not been cross examined on this aspect.

(15) As far as Sudhir is concerned, the testimony of 10 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 Pramod Kumar (PW-1) that Sudhir had thrown chili powder in the eye of deceased Vivek as has been expressed in Para 4 of examination-in-chief has remained unrebutted. In cross examination, in Para 21, Pramod Kumar (PW-1) has further categorically stated that act of Sudhir putting chili powder in the eye of Vivek and stabbing by co-accused Anil was such a quick succession when there was no time to save accused had ran away. In para 25 of his cross- examination, he has categorically stated that it is incorrect to say that at the time of incident Sudhir had Bamori. He further deposed that Sudhir was carrying chili in his hand. In fact, once this suggestion of Sudhir being away from the place of incident was given, as is reflected Para 25 of cross-examination, it was for the defence to have developed this alibi of absence of Sudhir should have been taken further but has been abruptly given up. Similarly, another eye witness Manish (PW-2) has deposed in Para 5 of his examination-in-chief that Sudhir had thrown chili powder in the eye of deceased Vivek. In cross-examination, on behalf of Sudhir, in Para 25, he has reiterated that one of the accused is present in the dock was carrying chili powder in his hands. Thus, as far as Sudhir is concerned, eye witnesses account remains un-rebutted in regard to his throwing chili powder in the eye of deceased, even his case is of premeditation and pre-planning along with co-accused Anil else normally a person moving on a road is not expected to carry chili powder in his pocket.

(16) Case of Vinod is different and finds support from the law laid down in the case of Bansant Lal (Supra). In fact, it is evident from testimony of Pramod Kumar (PW-1) that Anil had obstructed the way of Vivek and asked him as to why he had beaten him a day before. Vinod had caught 11 Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 hold the Vivek when Sudhir had put red chili powder in the eye of Vivek. It cannot be said that Vinod was already knowing the intention of Anil to cause stab wounds or vital blow to the deceased Vivek. It has come on record and has been admitted by Pramod Kumar (PW-1) that Anil had all of a sudden had taken out skewer (katar) from his pocket of trouser and had hit Vivek. This Act of Anil carrying a skewer (katar) and taking it out all of a sudden goes to show that merely holding hands of the deceased is not sufficient to establish common intention which presupposes prior concert or prearranged plan as held in the case of Pandurag (Supra). Therefore, merely on the statement of Pramod Kumar (PW-1) and Manish Jain (PW-

2), conviction of Vinod under Section 302 IPC with aid of Section 34 IPC cannot be sustained inasmuch as Manish Jain (PW-2) has himself admitted that game was over within 35 seconds. Therefore, Vinod in light of the ratio of law laid down in the case of Basant Lal (Supra) cannot be sustained as there is no evidence to show that Vinod was sharing intention or Anil exhorted Vinod to catch hold or Vinod exhorted Anil or anybody else to kill Vivek, therefore conviction of Vinod is entitled to be converted from Section 302/34 of IPC to Section 342 of IPC.

(17) Thus, appeals filed in respect of appellants Anil and Sudhir being devoid of merits deserve to be dismissed and are hereby dismissed.

(18) Appeal in respect of Vinod Kumar is partly allowed and his conviction under section 302/34 of IPC is converted into Section 342 of IPC and he is sentenced to undergo 1 year's R.I. and fine of Rs.1000/-, in default of fine amount, further 1 month R.I..

12

Criminal Appeal Nos. 294/2015 & 744/2005 (19) As per certificate under Section 428 Cr.P.C, appellant Vinod Kumar was in custody from 20.04.1998 to 23.08.1999 and 25.10.1999 to 18.10.2000, then from 17.01.2001 to 06.07.2001, thus he has already undergone considerable jail sentence; therefore, he is directed to deposit the fine amount (if already not deposited) within a period of four weeks from today. After depositing the fine amount, his bail bonds shall stand discharged.

(20) From record it appears that the appellant Sudhir is on bail. His bail bonds and surety bonds are hereby cancelled. The appellant Sudhir is directed to surrender immediately before the trial Court for undergoing the remaining jail sentence. Appellant Anil Bhargava is in jail. He shall suffer the sentence as imposed by the trial Court.

(21) Copy of the judgment be sent to the trial Court along with its record for information and compliance.
